title: Cochlear Implantation in Meningitis Caused by Streptococcus suis
chief_complaint: I lost my hearing suddenly after getting sick with meningitis three years ago. I tried hearing aids, but they don't help enough for me to understand people.

problem_summary.course: Acute onset following bacterial meningitis; slight improvement post-antibiotics but remained profound.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of fever, headache, myalgia (muscle pain), and general malaise associated with meningitis.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Profound hearing loss preventing effective communication; insufficient benefit from amplification.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient and family are motivated for rehabilitation via cochlear implantation.

history.present_illness: Patient contracted Streptococcus suis meningitis 3 years ago (likely via skin wounds while handling raw pork). Treated with ceftriaxone, linezolid, and dexamethasone. Hearing loss occurred shortly after admission.
history.otologic_history: No prior history mentioned before meningitis.
history.prior_management: Fitted with bilateral high-power hearing aids (Phonak Una SP AZ) 1 month post-meningitis. Trialed but provided limited benefit.
history.patient_goals: To improve speech understanding and communication.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. No responses noted at the limits of the audiometer for most frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Performed using the Hong Kong Speech Perception Test. Auditory-only scores are negligible/extremely poor. Visual cues (lipreading) provide some benefit but overall performance is low.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Aided sound-field thresholds obtained with Phonak Una SP AZ hearing aids. Thresholds fall at the lower edge of the speech banana, providing insufficient gain.

numeric_results.Aided_Response_4000Hz: No response at 80 dB HL limit

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Declined by patient; could not tolerate probe insertion and pressure change.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Radiologic evaluation (CT) performed 1 month post-meningitis. Revealed no significant cochlear abnormality at that time.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss secondary to bacterial meningitis. Pre-operative evaluation demonstrates that conventional high-power amplification provides insufficient functional gain (aided thresholds 55-65 dB HL) and negligible open-set speech understanding (0-3% auditory-only).
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is a direct result of the meningitis infection.
Current hearing aids are not providing enough volume or clarity for you to understand speech without lipreading.
Meningitis can cause the cochlea (inner ear) to turn to bone (ossify) very quickly. This makes cochlear implantation urgent.
We recommend proceeding with simultaneous bilateral cochlear implantation as soon as possible to ensure the electrodes can be fully inserted before any bone growth occurs.
While outcomes vary, a cochlear implant is the only option to potentially restore access to speech sounds.
notes_for_actor: You are a 66-year-old woman who survived a serious illness (meningitis) but lost your hearing.
You rely heavily on lipreading; if the audiologist covers their mouth, you cannot understand them.
You may be anxious about the surgery but are motivated because the hearing aids are not working.
You have a history of handling raw pork, which is how you contracted the infection (S. suis).
